investigation.title: Revenue from Theater Tickets
investigation.p: The local theater group sold tickets to its opening-night performance for $5 and drew an audience of 100 people. The next night they reduced the ticket price by $0.25 and 10 more people attended; that is, 110 people bought tickets at $4.75 apiece. In fact, for each $0.25 reduction in ticket price, 10 additional tickets can be sold.

subsection.title: Finding the Vertex
subsection.p: The vertex of a parabola ~y=ax^2+bx~ is an interesting point. It is the highest or lowest point on the parabola, and it "anchors" the parabola's position in the plane. As we saw in the Investigation, the vertex may represent the maximum or minimum possible value for a variable, so it has important implications for applications. Thus, it will be very useful to have a way to find the vertex easily.

In Section 3.3.5 we saw that the vertex of the graph of ~y=ax^2+bx~ has x-coordinate given by x_v=\dfrac{-b}{2a} Now we'll see that the same formula holds for any parabola. subsection.p: Once we know the vertex of a parabola, we can make a quick sketch of the graph.

statement.p: Sketch a graph of ~y=x^2+3x+1

solution.p: The vertex of the graph is given by x_v \amp = \dfrac{-b}{2a} = \dfrac{-3}{2(1)} = -1.5 y_v \amp = (-1.5)^2+3(-1.5)+1 =-1.25 The vertex is the point (-1.5,-1.25).

We set x=0 to find the y-intercept, (0,1). Now, the axis of symmetry of the parabola is the vertical line that passes through its vertex. That line is x=-1.5, so the y-intercept lies 1.5 units to the right of the axis. There must be another point on the parabola with the same y-coordinate as the intercept but 1.5 units to the left of the axis. This point is (-3,1).
By plotting the vertex, the y-intercept, and its symmetric point, we can make a quick sketch of the parabola, as shown below.
If we need more accuracy in our graph, we can find and plot more points, including the x-intercepts. ~\alert{\text{[TK]}}

subsection.title: Maximum or Minimum Values
subsection.p: Many quadratic models arise as the product of two variables, one of which increases while the other decreases. For example, in the Investigation for Section 3.3 we looked at the areas of different rectangles with the same perimeter. The area of a rectangle is the product of its length and its width, or A=lw. If we require that the rectangle have a certain perimeter, then as we increase its length, we must also decrease its width.

Finding the maximum or minimum value for a variable expression is a common problem in applications. For example, if you own a company that manufactures blue jeans, you might like to know how much to charge for your jeans in order to maximize your revenue. As you increase the price of the jeans, your revenue may increase for a while. But if you charge too much for the jeans, consumers will not buy as many pairs, and your revenue may actually start to decrease. Is there some optimum price you should charge for a pair of jeans in order to achieve the greatest revenue?

statement.p:
Late Nite Blues finds that it can sell 600 - 15x pairs of jeans per week if it charges x dollars per pair. (Notice that as the price increases, the number of pairs of jeans sold decreases.)
Write an equation for the revenue as a function of the price of a pair of jeans.
Graph the function.
How much should Late Nite Blues charge for a pair of jeans in order to maximize its revenue?

li.p: Using the formula for revenue stated above, we find \text{Revenue} \amp= (\text{price of one item})(\text{number of items sold}) R \amp = x(600 - 15x) R \amp = 600x - 15x^2
We recognize the equation as quadratic, so the graph is a parabola. You can use your calculator to verify the graph below.

image.description: graph showing revenue from sales of jeans

li.p: As you can see from the graph, the maximum value of R occurs at the vertex of the parabola. Thus, x_v\amp=\frac{-b}{2a}=\frac{-600}{2(-15)}=20 y_v\amp=600(\alert{20}) - 15(\alert{20})^2 = 6000 The revenue takes on its maximum value when x = 20, and the maximum value is R = 6000. This means that Late Nite Blues should charge $20 for a pair of jeans in order to maximize revenue at $6000 a week.

note.p: If the equation relating two variables is quadratic, then the maximum or minimum value is easy to find: It is the value at the vertex. If the parabola opens downward, as in , there is a maximum value at the vertex. subsection.title: The Vertex Form for a Parabola
subsection.p: Because the vertex is such a useful tool, we introduce a new form for a quadratic equation. Consider the equation y = 2(x - 3)^2 - 8 By expanding the squared expression ~\alert{\text{[TK]}} and collecting like terms, we can rewrite the equation in standard form as y \amp= 2(x^2 - 6x + 9) - 8 y \amp = 2x^2 - 12x + 10

sidebyside.p: The vertex of this parabola is x_v \amp= \frac{-(-12)}{2(2)}=3 y_v \amp = 2(3)^2 - 12(3) + 10=-8 and its graph is shown at right.

assemblage.title: Vertex Form for a Quadratic Equation

statement.p: Find the vertex of the graph of y = -3(x - 4)^2 + 6. Is the vertex a maximum or a minimum point of the graph?

solution.p: We compare the equation to the vertex form to see that the coordinates of the vertex are (4, 6). For this equation, a = -3 \lt 0, so the parabola opens downward. The vertex is the maximum point of the graph.

subsection.p: To understand why the vertex form works, substitute x_v = \alert{4} into y = -3(x - 4)^2 + 6 from to find y = -3(\alert{4} - 4)^2 + 6 = 6 which confirms that when x = 4, y = 6. Next, notice that if x is any number except 4, the expression -3(x - 4)^2 is negative, so y \lt 6. Therefore, 6 is the maximum value for y on the graph, so (4, 6) is the high point or vertex.
You can also rewrite y = -3(x - 4)^2 + 6 in standard form and use the formula x_v = \dfrac{-b}{2a} to confirm that the vertex is the point (4, 6).

subsection.p: Any quadratic equation in vertex form can be written in standard form by expanding, and any quadratic equation in standard form can be put into vertex form by completing the square. ~\alert{\text{[TK]}} completing the square

statement.p: Write the equation y = 3x^2 - 6x - 1 in vertex form and find the vertex of its graph.

solution.p: We factor the lead coefficient, 3, from the variable terms, leaving a space to complete the square. y = 3(x^2 - 2x ) - 1 Next, we complete the square inside parentheses. Take half the coefficient of x and square the result: p = \frac{1}{2}(-2) = -1,~~\text{and}~~ p^2 = (-1)^2 = 1 We must add 1 to complete the square. However, we are really adding 3(1) to the right side of the equation, so we must also subtract 3 to compensate: y = 3(x^2 - 2x \alert{{}+{}1}) - 1\,\alert{-\,3} The expression inside parentheses is now a perfect square, and the vertex form is y = 3(x - 1)^2 - 4 The vertex of the parabola is (1,-4).

statement.p:
When Andre practices free-throws at the park, the ball leaves his hands at a height of 7 feet, and reaches the vertex of its trajectory 10 feet away at a height of 11 feet.
Find a quadratic equation for the ball's trajectory.
Do you think Andre's free-throw would score on a regulation basketball court, where the hoop is 15 feet from the shooter and 10 feet high?

li.p: If Andre's feet are at the origin, then the vertex of the ball's trajectory is the point (\alert{10},\alert{11}), and its y-intercept is (0,7). We start with the vertex form for a parabola. y \amp =a(x-x_v)^2+y_v y \amp =a(x-\alert{10})^2+\alert{11} We use the point (0,7) to find the value of a. \alert{7} \amp = a(\alert{0}-10)^2+11 7 \amp= 100a+11 a \amp = -0.04 The equation of the trajectory is ~y=-0.04(x-10)^2+11.

We'd like to know if the point (15,10) is on the trajectory of Andre's free-throw. We substitute x=\alert{15} into the equation. y \amp =-0.04(\alert{15}-10)^2+11 y \amp =-0.04(25)+11 = 10 From our computations, we see that the point (15,10) is indeed on the trajectory. However, because Andre's shot will probably hit the backboard just where the hoop attaches and bounce off, so it is unlikely that his shot will score.
